title: Wednesday, 4th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Suppose there's an obvious pic for today

PM11:01am

Theresa

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Ms May

PM11:01am

PM11:02am

Who'd have thought that she reads -- and sets policy -- as per what Bryce says in ML

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But it's happened

PM11:02am

https://www.ft.com...-93c5-648314d2c72c

PM11:02am

To be fair, it was probably one of her flunkies rather than Theresa herself

11:02 am
PM11:02am

She'll have been too busy

PM11:03am

But the fact remains: Bryce's outburst yesterday caused the government of today to alter housing policy

undefined
11:04 am
PM11:04am

But that was yesterday's theme

PM11:05am

Today we're looking for something fresh

PM11:05am

Looking

11:04 am
PM11:05am

and looking

PM11:05am

and looking

PM11:05am

Cos corporate news has slowed to a trickle

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Why is this?

PM11:05am

Footsie becalmed at an index level.

PM11:05am

Again

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Where do we go? Utilities?

BE11:06am

Well there's Tesco of course. And Centrica, which is politics.

BE11:06am

But we can't really ignore the noise on the right.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Which is S&N.

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,387, up 13 (+0.95%), High: 1,387, Low: 1,370, Volume: 2.79m
BE11:07am

And to be particularly annoying, I'm going to go into this somewhat backwards.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

er, go on

BE11:07am

Historically, in fact, apropos of this: https://www.cnbc.c...s-twitter-bid.html

BE11:07am

Disney was considering Twitter purchase before taking majority stake in BAMTech, Iger says

11:07 am
BE11:08am

So ................

BE11:08am

This needs a little context. It'll take a while but I'll get to the point eventually.

PM11:08am

Ok everyone on the right -- pay attention here!

11:08 am
BE11:08am

In the last week of October, a story went around that Twitter's board had provisionally agreed the terms of a takeover by Disney.

PM11:08am

I know where Bryce is going with this...

BE11:08am

To be clear, even then, it was quite an old story.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

There were lots of reports around earlier in October that Disney had a look in what was an unofficial sort of auction but decided not to proceed.

BE11:09am

You remember the stuff about Salesforce and ect.

BE11:09am

However, this new story was much more specific. This is October 2016, to be clear, just in case this stuff is setting off any badly programmed bots.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The story went that JP Morgan and Guggenheim were advising Disney on a formal bid and the proposal was being led by Kevin Mayer, Disney's senior VP and Chief Strategy Officer.

BE11:09am

So ..... We took it back to people familiar with the companies' strategy and thinking and whatnot. Which is what we do.

BE11:10am

And were told -- very very strongly but in an unquotable ways -- that Disney + Twitter was absolutely not happening.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Whatever interest Disney had in Twitter before is not there now, we were told.

BE11:10am

And I know for a fact that the same message given to other news organisations, who were chasing an identical version of the story.

PM11:11am

The news was stale. end of

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Yep. So ..... we reported nothing. And they reported nothing. Nothing was reported.

BE11:11am

So, shortly after, when the reports popped up that Disney was poised to bid for Twitter, it left us a bit stuck.

BE11:11am

Either we were being lied to -- which is possible! It happens! -- and the deal was still alive.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Or we weren't being lied to, the deal was absolutely definitely dead, and those new reports were based on less information than we had.

BE11:12am

Which is just a bloody mess, in terms of price discovery. And of course, an easy way to cut through all of this is for people to just speak on the record.

BE11:12am

If something's not true, just say so! And let us report that! Honestly, what's the downside?

11:12 am
BE11:12am

It does shareholders no favours whatsoever to have to rely on price-sensitive information being filtered through this secret society of people familiar with strategy and thinking and whatnot.

BE11:13am

........ So, anyway, that's a roundabout way to explain that Smith & Nephew is a stock we're not mentioning.

BE11:13am

We're not mentioning Smith & Nephew.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We're choosing not to mention right now, and that decision is based on conversations with people familiar with strategy and thinking and whatnot.

BE11:13am

So now, if and when some other media does report something on Smith & Nephew, you'll have to guess whether they've taken that choice based on more info than us, or less.

BE11:13am

Great eh! Efficient markets.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Feel free to do your own fantasy M&A though. Gabelli & Company can supply some charts.

BE11:14am

Market shares here:

BE11:14am

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BE11:14am

And some sector transactions:

BE11:14am

11:14 am
BE11:15am

And now, a separator.

undefined
PM11:15am

Thanks for that teach in

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Thumbs up

PM11:15am

You've just knocked C&N off the leader board

PM11:15am

Just like that

11:15 am
PM11:15am

There's real price discovery for you

BE11:16am

Adding noise to noise. We do what we can, in challenging conditions.

PM11:16am

S&N not C&N

11:16 am
undefined
PM11:16am

Centrica

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 180.87, down 10.03 (-5.25%), High: 191.10, Low: 180.70, Volume: 17.42m
11:16 am
PM11:16am

As you say, this is politics

BE11:16am

This is Theresa May communicating policy via the Sun again.

BE11:17am

This is now the third time, I think, that Theresa has announced an energy price cap via the Sun.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

First time was when she announced it, second time was when she rowed it back, and today we get it announced again.

BE11:17am

Albeit in terms so vague as to be totally meaningless.

BE11:18am

a cap that'll "save average consumers c.£100 per year."

11:18 am
BE11:18am

What does this mean in practice? We've absolutely no idea.

BE11:18am

Here's Citi, who have no idea either.

BE11:19am

In our view, £100/customer average reduction to bills could materially impact those UK utilities with a large supply customer base. We highlight in Figure 1 the latest number of SVT accounts held by each supplier and outline the potential EBIT impact for each of the UK suppliers. It is worth flagging that we have used the average August 2017 SVT tariff from the 6 large suppliers, and there will be differences in SVT tariffs which may skew the actual impact for each company. In addition, it is worth mentioning that each company would be likely to implement cost reduction programs on the back of such price cap, which would likely limit the % EBIT impact we outline in Figure 1.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Figure 1:

BE11:19am

PM11:20am

Blimey -- this really does hit Centrica

11:19 am
PM11:20am

Whatever it is

PM11:20am

Twice as hard as anyone else

BE11:21am

That's the thing. We keep on getting this price cap threatened without detail and it sinks Centrica, and then the detail arrives that triggers a rally, and nothing actually happens so repeat and repeat and repeat.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

It's the markets' little Beckett play in miniature.

BE11:23am

Credit Suisse ....................

BE11:23am

To recall, Greg Clark wrote to OFGEM on 21 June flagging the Conservative manifesto promise to "extend the price protection currently in place for some vulnerable customers to more customers on the poorest value tariffs." He asked OFGEM to look at safeguarding customers on the poorest tariffs, ensuring micro businesses are fairly treated and considering the future of standard variable tariffs.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

■ OFGEM then announced on 3 July that it was starting work with consumer groups on “measures to protect and empower vulnerable consumers”. It specifically highlighted options “including extending the current safeguard tariff in place for consumers on prepayment meters”. Press speculation (e.g. in The Telegraph) mentioned a number of 2.2m vulnerable customers. Centrica have c0.2m of these and have already frozen prices.
■ But there appears to be a point of disagreement. The energy minister has been quoted as saying “I won’t rest until the detriment consumers are suffering is eradicated”, and
appears to believe OFGEM has the power to cap prices (the implication seems to us to be for the whole market; something only one dissenting view in the CMA report agreed with). OFGEM have interpreted the Electricity Act to mean that market-wide price caps should be a matter decided in Parliament. OFGEM would also expect an appeal to the appeals body – the CMA or perhaps even the CAT - and seek to avoid this.

BE11:24am

■ Our view is that price caps will reduce competition, reduce choice, and ultimately mean
higher prices and more market power for incumbents. The big six will resort to cost-out
and have more stable (and potentially higher) margins. We note that the Northern Irish incumbent electricity supplier (Power NI) still has c63% market share and is regulated at a c2.2% EBIT margin (albeit it is reported with other profits).
■ Around c15% of the GB market is currently on price caps set at c£1040 per household (inc. VAT), on standard consumption figures. This includes c£30 (3%) headroom and £64 for additional costs of prepayment meters. It will rise over the coming year due to higher commodity prices. The price was set from a theoretical average of c3% margin on top of the average price of two established new entrants (Ovo and FU). The average standard variable tariff is £1,136 per account.
■ If the price cap was extended to another c8% of the market (e.g. customers on the warm homes discount) then the adverse impact on supplier profits would be c£200m, of which c£20m would be with British Gas and c£30m SSE. Those customers would be paying c£930, after the warm homes discount. Around c12m households (c22m accounts) would still be on standard variable tariffs. These c12m households would then inevitably become the point of contention.

PM11:25am

This is looking like a real muddle

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Indeed ......... and this is only the latest chapter in the epic story of Machiavellian political wrangling about whether six power companies will have to charge some customers slightly less for electricity.

BE11:25am

Good luck with Brexit everyone.

undefined
11:25 am
PM11:25am

Thanks for that

PM11:26am

Move on to Tesco?

PM11:26am

I don't see why this interims have gone down badly

11:26 am
BE11:26am

It's back down. It's been up, then down, then up again and now back down.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 187.15, down 2.9 (-1.53%), High: 194.00, Low: 183.40, Volume: 39.34m
PM11:26am

Interims here https://www.invest...1710040700056178S/

11:26 am
BE11:26am

The numbers are fine at the headline and a bit rubbish at the detail.

BE11:27am

Which shows International carrying things, as well as a property gain that is (to state the obvious) a one-off.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:27 am
PM11:28am

And the divis back!

BE11:28am

Yes! Which was expected, and in all the weekend press. What wasn't was UK ex-fuel LFL at 2.1% against a consensus of 2.5%.

PM11:28am

hmm

11:28 am
BE11:29am

So ..... it's a story of the UK still being a bit more tricky than expected.

BE11:30am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:30am

Conclusion: Upbeat results from TSCO, with international driving a beat and the UK
broadly slightly light (on Q2 LFL and margin). This should help underpin the stock's recent
gains. Still, ongoing pension top-ups (the actuarial deficit has actually increased by £250m
since the last triannual review) will continue to result in a disconnect between P/E (now
16.3x cal 2018) and FCY (of 5.5% in 2018).
Details: TSCO reported H1 group EBIT growth of 27% (24% ex fx) to £759m (JEFe/cons of
£692m/£703m). UK LFL slowed in Q2 (to +2.1% after +2.3% in Q1; JEF/e cons 2.5%) and
UK/ROI margin gains of +31bps compare to JEFe/cons of +24bps/36bps). The group beat
was all due to international (given a mixture of reduced promos and opex savings; Q2 sales
were actually weaker) given a 134bps gain. Cashflow looks stronger, helped working capital
gains, with YoY net debt falling £1.1bn to £3.3bn. IAS deficit has reduced from £5.5bn with the finals to £2.4bn now. A 1p interim dividend is announced.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:31am

Overall, numbers should be taken well: while UK 2Q18 LFL sales came in a touch below consensus expectations (+2.1% vs. +2.5%), Group underlying operating profit was above (by 3%, when one strips out property profits) as international operations’ margin expanded more than expected. On the back of today’s results, we expect consensus FY18 EPS to go up by ~4%. The other important piece of news relates to the pension deficit: a) the size of the deficit was substantially below market expectations (£3.0bn triennial valuation vs. ~£5bn expected by consensus. The ~£2.0bn gap is 25p per share); b) the cash contribution will only go up by £15m per annum (i.e. to £285m), while some of the bears had speculated that it could go as high as ~£500m.

BE11:32am

And Bernstein.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Net pension deficit reduced from £5,504m to £2,439m. There are 2 new valuations. The independent triennial is at £3 billion, the accounting version down to £2.4 billion. The accounting version drop is a combination of 'standard' changes (asset valuation, experience gains, etc.) and an adjustment to the discount rate, bringing it closer in line with IAS19 guidance (i.e from long dated gilts to a corporate bond equivalent long term yield).

Pension drop in itself warrants a 20% share price increase or 30p on the shares.

BE11:34am

........ so, lower food inflation. Slightly puffed out bottom line from £33m of property profits. No one seems to care about the pension thing for reasons I don't quite grasp. Shares down. That's Tesco.

PM11:34am

hmm

11:34 am
undefined
PM11:35am

Royal Mail keeps getting mentioned

PM11:35am

But I have nothing on it

11:34 am
PM11:35am

Do you?

BE11:35am

Strike!

BE11:35am

A few things, mostly stating the obvious.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

The strike vote is overwhelming

BE11:36am

Yep. CWU has voted for strike action in rather large numbers, which was the expected outcome.

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 374.20, down 10 (-2.60%), High: 381.40, Low: 368.30, Volume: 4.92m
11:36 am
BE11:36am

We're now facing the first national strike since forever.

BE11:37am

Which is pretty much irrelevant for Royal Mail's numbers, as the letters just sit in the postbox for a wee bit longer .......

BE11:37am

.... but rather bad, goes the theory, for Royal Mail's reputation.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Because all Royal Mail has really is reliability.

BE11:37am

As in, the relief when you see your Amazon parcel is coming via them rather than Yodel.

BE11:37am

A strike unravels that a wee bit.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Here's RBC ............

BE11:39am

We think strikes risk material damage to all of RMG's stakeholders: Our view is because:
• Letters substitution by digital media is likely to accelerate - with volume potentially never returning once other media have been found for it or customers change their habits.
• Parcel volumes and contract loss to key competitors looks likely - and this is market share that might never return.
• Network costs are not as easily reduced short-term as share is lost.
Even with employee wages not paid during a strike and loss of Christmas overtime we think financial projection downgrades for fixed network costs and lost revenues in the short-term, will also see softer future profits as market share is lost.
• In our view, this would accelerate a longer-term requirement for much larger redundancies in future after a strike, should a smaller volume pool mean accelerated automation is required.
• Though Royal Mail may disagree with us, in our view in a combative industrial relations environment (anyway) there might then be little to lose from re-setting RMG to more efficient peer levels of productivity on a quicker trajectory.

BE11:39am

Overall, bad news all round: A risk of less volume, and higher costs would, we think, make even the current pension proposals less affordable, damage the business long-term (permanent share loss) and reduce shareholder value - including reducing the value of shares held by employees.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

As to where the negotiations actually stand .....

BE11:40am

The current share price reflects Royal Mail's latest proposals, in our view, including wage inflation of 1.5%-1.9% vs. CWU 5% and a pension cash contribution of £400m vs. CWU £500m.

BE11:40am

That's Jefferies, who add:

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Our base-case scenario arrives at a fair value of 320p based on a pension cash contribution of £400m and wage inflation of 2.1%, while we had earlier estimated a fair value of 150p based on the CWU proposals. Key risk factors include diminishing e-substitution in a relatively resilient post-Brexit UK economy, accelerating e-commerce-driven parcel growth and a relatively more favourable outcome of the labour negotiations.

undefined
PM11:42am

Amazon / Lux mentioned on the right

11:42 am
PM11:42am

I should just share the press release on this

PM11:42am

Which is in slightly broken English, with an unbroken english translation

PM11:42am

uxembourg comments on Commission decision in Amazon case (04.10.2017)

Luxembourg has taken note of the Commission's decision in the Amazon case. He will analyze it with due diligence and reserve all his rights.

The Commission's decision refers to an era dating back to 2006. In the meantime, the relevant international and Luxembourg rules have changed considerably. Whereas Amazon was imposed in accordance with the tax rules in force at the relevant time, Luxembourg considers that it did not provide the company with State aid incompatible with the internal market within the meaning of of Article 107 (1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

11:42 am
PM11:43am

Communicated by the Ministry of Finance

PM11:43am

And then...

PM11:43am

English translation

Luxembourg on the Commission's decision in the Amazon case (04.10.2017)

Luxembourg has taken note of the decision by the European Commission in the Amazon case. Luxembourg will use its due diligence to analyze the decision and reserves all its rights.

The decision of the European Commission on the revision of the European Social Charter. (1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. (2).

Luxembourg has been fully cooperating with the Commission in its investigation and is strongly committed to tax transparency and the fight against harmful tax avoidance. Luxembourg fully adheres to the OECD / G20 BEPS project, which modernizes international tax rules and creates a global level playing field.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Translation of the translation...

PM11:43am

We're gonna drag our feet

undefined
11:44 am
BE11:45am

Anglo leading us up again.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,417, up 19.5 (+1.40%), High: 1,418, Low: 1,394, Volume: 1.51m
BE11:45am

Becoming a trend, that.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Three's the obvious reason, which we've mentioned several times this week already.

BE11:46am

And then there's the less obvious reason, which was a De Beers presentation earlier in the week.

BE11:46am

With CFO Nimesh Patel

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Which has led to some positive comment from the likes of RBC.

BE11:48am

Due to the opaque nature of the diamond market, the true value of Anglo American's De Beers subsidiary can often be overlooked in assessing
the investment case. Yesterday's De Beers presentation should help to increase rigor in analysis around the profitability and cashflows of the
division (with its highly complex accounting) and especially help to provide focus on the Trading division. This division will provide RBCe 2017
EBITDA of $444m vs. total De Beers EBITDA of $1.6bn and as it effectively comes at a ~7% EBITDA margin mark-up over consolidated revenues (this is effectively the fee for sorting, aggregating, selling, marketing spend, etc). As we have highlighted previously, the volatility around this Trading EBITDA over the cycle is significantly lower than typical industrial mining operations. This division would be analogous to Glencore's marketing business, albeit it would use lower capital (but is also smaller scale). We calculate a ROCE for Trading of c. 45% based on guidance that inventories account for 1.5x of a sales cycle.

BE11:48am

In addition, the agreement with the Government of Botswana sees Anglo take 19.2% of the Debswana JV economics but they do not pay tax.
While this is well understood, it also means that its reported EBITDA from the high margin JV of RBC FY17e $541m already includes an "effective
tax" within it - equivalent to c. $150m of "unrecognised" EBITDA (assuming an arbitrary 30% tax rate). In theory, this, and the lower volatility of the Trading EBITDA should mean nearly $1 billion of De Beers EBITDA should trade at a premium multiple. With De Beers’ RBCe FY17 EBITDA of
$1.6bn accounting for 20% of our base case $8.1bn EBITDA, this appears to not be priced into the current valuation of 4.3x 2017e EBITDA (or
3.7x 2018e EBITDA) vs. peers at 5.0x and sector normalised at 6.5x. Considering De Beers' leading position in the diamond industry (with still solid long-term growth prospects), we believe De Beers is underappreciated within Anglo American and adds to what we see as a compelling value within the wider Anglo American investment case.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Not sure about the parallel between De Beers' attempted stranglehold on the diamond supply chain and Glencore's trading business .......

BE11:49am

Can't really see the similarity, But, hey, it's your money.

undefined
11:49 am
PM11:50am

See BT's up

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 280.60, up 1.25 (+0.45%), High: 282.20, Low: 279.40, Volume: 5.39m
PM11:50am

A tad

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But I see Morgan Stanley suggesting the dividend is at risk

PM11:50am

That would be rather dramatic

BE11:51am

Hm ...........

11:50 am
BE11:51am

It's a question that's been raised a few times.

PM11:51am

Suppose they could invest in fibre before paying out the shareholders -- that would be a novelty

PM11:52am

Actually, MOST citing the appearance of the new FD

11:52 am
PM11:52am

And conditions being similar to the last time BT cut the divi

PM11:52am

2009

PM11:52am

I'll let them speak

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Hm. Cancelling the divi to fund the purchase of EPL football rights would be a bit unpopular I suspect.

BE11:52am

It's the kind of thing that'd cost a CEO his job. But, yes, let's hear them out.

PM11:53am

Conditions today are similar to those around the dividend cut in 2009. BT last cut its dividend in 2009 (down 61% YoY) following management changes, a profit warning in Global Services and rising pension payments. The situation in 2017 looks similar with (1) a new Chairman and CFO appointed; (2) a profit warning following accounting fraud in Italy; (3) an upcoming triennial pension review where we forecast the deficit has ballooned to £13bn from £7bn previously. In addition, BT faces an additional cash call from fibre investments, which we believe cannot be absorbed into the existing capex budget, as was the case for their VDSL (fibre to the cabinet) upgrade plan in 2009

11:52 am
PM11:53am

Around 30% downside risk to the dividend. In May, management dropped its dividend commitment of "at least 10% growth" to "progressive", but this may not be far enough. BT's dividend payout has been creeping up from 28% of normalised free cash flow in 2009 to 55% of FCF today. However, adding on inevitable fibre spend and higher pension payments, the payout ratio could reach 90-100%. With the potential for big cash outflows - we estimate c.£6bn for fibre over 7 years, c.£3bn for pension over 3 years - a reset of the dividend back to a 40% payout could be possible. This would imply a 30% reduction in dividend taking the FY18e dividend to c.11p or 4% dividend yield.

PM11:53am

Stock view: YTD BT shares are down 23% and appear to be in a holding pattern. We think there is uncertainty around the shares because over the last 20 years, BT has seen three sharp and prolonged corrections making the bottom tough to call. The 2009 bull market rally in BT shares only really gathered pace once clarity emerged over guidance, capex and pension. Our PT falls to 320p due to downgrades to our forecasts for the Business and Public Sector unit.

PM11:53am

So target price cut from 350p to 320p

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Well, okay.

BE11:54am

Did you notice the English Championship rights auction a few days ago?

PM11:54am

Nope

11:54 am
BE11:54am

As in, rights for 2019-2024. Sky paid £600m

BE11:54am

As in, £125m per year.

BE11:55am

That's 36% more than the £88m paid last time around.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

For a second-rate schedule filler product that's haemorrhaging viewers.

BE11:56am

And that's the bidding market BT's about to step into, and in which we have reported interest from Amazon and Facebook and who knows who else, as well as the cornered rat incumbent.

BE11:57am

If BT cuts its divi for sports rights then I'd suggest that 320p target on the Morgan Stanley note is too high by about 100p.

11:57 am
undefined
BE11:58am

Few minutes left. Topps Tiles requested.

BE11:58am

Warning. Again.

11:58 am
Topps Tiles PLC (TPT:LSE): Last: 72.75, down 2 (-2.68%), High: 73.00, Low: 67.25, Volume: 565.41k
BE11:58am

Q4 bad. Outlook worse.

PM11:59am

This is general consumer slowdown stuff?

11:59 am
BE11:59am

"Market conditions remain challenging" is the banal reason they gave.

BE11:59am

Like-for-like revenues fell 3% in Q4 to end September, which is worse than the 2.9% for the year overall.

BE11:59am

So, guiding earnings to the lower end of the current range of market expectations.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Price tells us we kinda knew already.

BE12:00pm

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE12:01pm

We cut [FY PTP] by 3% to £18.5m to reflect the lower sales outcome. While there is a sense that autumn sales show some signs of stability, we cut our FY2018 by 12% to £17.7m, which is as much a function of costs as revenues. As ever, Topps continues to take market share and maintains a dominant market position. Trading on 10x, the shares reflect forecast momentum rather than market position and balance sheet.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Fairly sure they're shop.

BE12:01pm

And Canaccord.

BE12:02pm

The question here has to be what could, or should, Topps do differently? We see it as a well-run business with a consistent track record of taking market share. Store growth has been more disciplined than many in the sector and costs have been tightly controlled. The focus on a service-based proposition, combined with keen pricing, has allowed it to hold its own against the big box retailers as well as the independents. A move into smaller, boutique stores has allowed it to reach previously untapped catchments. The acquisition of a small commercial business
announced today, more details with prelims on 28 November) opens up a new and potentially material long-term growth opportunity.
Despite all of these positives, the fact that Topps has a third of the domestic tiles market and is a tightly run ship means that it is hard to sail against the current. There are few levers to pull to drive profit growth in the absence of LFL sales. A fixed charge cover of 1.7x means that the balance sheet is not strong enough for surplus cash returns to shareholders, albeit we still expect a greater than 4% dividend yield. Reflecting the cut to our estimates, offset by lower capex assumptions, our price target falls from 84p to 78p. Our target price is DCF derived and we use a 0% terminal growth rate given the cyclical nature of the market. The shares trade on a calendar 2018E PE of 10x on our new numbers, which we think is fair in the context of the current forecast agenda. Maintain HOLD

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Thanks for all that

undefined
PM12:03pm
